questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following conditions is unlikely to lead to cirrhosis in a patient?
questions.explanation:
Hepatitis A infection is an acute self-limiting condition that does not lead to cirrhosis. Cirrhosis is a late stage of chronic liver disease pathologically characterized by hepatic fibrosis, 
distortion of hepatic architecture, and formation of regenerative nodules. The causes of cirrhosis are: • Chronic viral hepatitis - Hepatitis B and C • Alcoholic liver disease • Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease 338 
Sold by @itachibot • Autoimmune hepatitis • Biliary cirrhosis - • Primary biliary cholangitis • Primary sclerosing cholangitis • Cardiac cirrhosis • Inherited metabolic liver diseases - • Cystic fibrosis • Hemochromatosis • Wilson's disease • 1 Antitrypsin deficiency • Cryptogenic cirrhosis • Drugs - methotrexate, isoniazid

questions.question:
Question 2: While examining a chronic alcoholic patient, you notice the given finding. Which of the 
following is false regarding it?

options.a: Occurs due to alterations in the metabolism of estrogen
options.b: Presence of even 1 lesion is abnormal
options.c: Commonly seen over the superior vena cava territory
options.d: Compression results in blanching followed by reappearance after release

questions.explanation:
The given image shows spider telangiectasia and the presence of >2 to 3 of these are considered 
abnormal. Spider telangiectasias are dilated arterioles with a prominent central arteriole with radiating 
vessels appearing in the shape of a spider. They are generally seen in the superior vena cava 
territory. Compression results in blanching followed by reappearance after the release of pressure. 
They occur due to a hyperestrogenic state which is caused by defective estrogen metabolism in 
liver cirrhosis. Clinical features seen in cirrhosis include: • Spider telangiectasias • Palmar erythema • Terry's nails - pallor of the proximal nail bed • Clubbing • Gynaecomastia • Caput medusae - dilated abdominal veins. • Parotid enlargement The image below shows Terry's nails. 339 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is a posthepatic cause of portal hypertension?
questions.explanation:
Budd-Chiari syndrome is a posthepatic cause of portal hypertension. Budd Chiari syndrome is a congestive hepatopathy characterized by the obstruction of hepatic 
venous outflow. The most common cause is due to hepatic vein thrombosis. Obstruction of two or 340 
Sold by @itachibot more major hepatic veins causes Budd-Chiari syndrome. It is characterized by hepatomegaly, 
ascites, and abdominal pain.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following drugs is used to reduce the intrahepatic resistance in portal 
hypertension?
questions.explanation: Carvedilol is used to reduce the intrahepatic resistance in portal hypertension. The pharmacologic management of portal hypertension includes: • Drugs that reduce the portal blood flow • Non-selective  blockers - Propranolol and nadolol are preferred • Somatostatin and its analogs - Octreotide, lanreotide, and vapreotide • Vasopressin and analogs - Terlipressin • Drugs that decrease the intrahepatic resistance • Carvedilol - due to its  blockade property

questions.question:
Question 6: Ascitic tap done on a patient with abdominal distention revealed a SAAG of 1.4g/dL. What is 
the likely cause of his ascites?
questions.explanation: The serum ascites albumin gradient of 1.1g/dL is suggestive of portal hypertension. SAAG helps distinguish ascites caused by portal hypertension from other causes of ascites.

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient presented with massive abdominal swelling. Paracentesis fluid was sent for lab 
analysis and results show serum protein to be 3g/dL and ascitic fluid protein to be 1g/dL. 
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario with serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) 
>1.1g/dL [calculated as serum albumin level - ascitic fluid albumin level, which in this case is 
3-1=2g/dL] and ascitic fluid protein <2.5 g/dL is late Budd Chiari syndrome. Serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) can be used to differentiate between ascites due to portal 
hypertension and non-portal hypertensive ascites. It represents the pressure within the hepatic 
sinusoids and correlates with the hepatic venous pressure gradient. It is given by the formula: SAAG = Serum albumin level - Ascitic fluid albumin level Interpretation of SAAG: • SAAG 1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It 
reflects the presence of portal hypertension. • SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to 
infection or malignancy. In cases with high-SAAG (1.1), ascitic protein level analysis further helps in identifying the 
etiology: 341 
Sold by @itachibot • 2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing the passage of protein 
into the ascites as in early Budd-Chiari syndrome. • <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer 
allow passage of protein as in late Budd-Chiari syndrome

questions.question: Question 8: A patient is said to have refractory ascites if the ascites does not resolve even after:
questions.explanation: Refractory ascites is defined as the inability to mobilize ascitic fluid despite: • Compliance with dietary sodium restriction • Administration of maximum doses of diuretics - • 400mg of spironolactone per day and • 160mg of furosemide per day

questions.question:
Question 9: What is the minimum absolute neutrophilic count that should be present in the ascitic fluid 
to diagnose a patient with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis?
questions.explanation:
The diagnosis of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis(SBP) is made when the fluid sample has an 
absolute neutrophil count >250/L. SBP is the spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. Infection 
with E.coli and other gut bacteria is most commonly seen. However, gram-positive bacteria like 
Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus, and Enterococcus sp., can also be 
found. Abdominal paracentesis is the investigation of choice. It can be managed with antibiotic 
therapy.

questions.question:
Question 10: A cirrhotic patient admitted for ascites complained of abdominal pain on the 2nd day of his 
hospital stay. On examination, he was febrile. His lab reports are given below. Which of the 
following is false about his condition?

options.a: E.coli is the most commonly isolated organism
options.b: Prophylaxis against this condition is recommended in upper GI bleed
options.c: Third generation cephalosporins are used for treatment
options.d: Weekly antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended to prevent recurrence

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with ANC  250 cells/l in ascitic fluid is suggestive of 
spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). Daily antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended in patients 
who have had an episode of SBP to prevent a recurrence. SBP is the spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. The most 
common causative organisms are E.coli and other gut bacteria. The diagnosis of SBP is made 
when the ascitic fluid has an absolute neutrophil count >250/l. According to the latest recommendations, weekly antibiotic prophylaxis is no longer 
recommended. For patients with low protein ascites (<1.5 g/dL [15g/L]) along with either 
impaired renal function or liver failure, we use prolonged 
outpatient trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (one double-strength tablet daily). Alternatives include 
ciprofloxacin 500 mg per day or norfloxacin 400 mg per day. For patients on chronic trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole therapy, renal function should be 
monitored by checking serum electrolytes, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine every one to 
six months depending on the stability of patient. If there is worsening renal function, 342 
Sold by @itachibot trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole should be discontinued.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following cannot be used to predict the risk of bleeding of oesophageal varices?
questions.explanation:
The risk of bleeding in a patient with oesophageal varices cannot be predicted based on the 
number of varices present. The factors that are used to predict the risk of variceal bleeding are: • Severity of cirrhosis (Child’s class, MELD score) • History of a previous variceal bleed • Location of the varices - varices with a thinner layer of supporting tissue are likely to bleed more • Size of the varices - larger varices have a higher risk of bleeding • Endoscopic appearance of varices - Presence of red wale sign, hematocystic spots, diffuse 
erythema, and cherry red spots are associated with increased risk of bleeding • Variceal pressure

questions.question:
Question 12: In a patient with which of the following conditions would you not recommend a transjugular 
intrahepatic portosystemic shunt?
questions.explanation:
Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is not recommended in hepatic 
encephalopathy as it can aggravate its symptoms. TIPS creates a low-resistance channel between the hepatic vein and an intrahepatic branch of the 
portal vein. It uses a percutaneous approach under angiographic guidance. This reduces portal 
pressure. It is used in the management of: • Oesophageal varices - in patients who fail medical or endoscopic management and have a poor 
surgical outcome • Refractory ascites • Gastric varices • Ectopic varices • Portal hypertensive gastropathy • Hepatorenal syndrome • Budd Chiari syndrome 343 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A middle-aged man with hematemesis is rushed to the casualty. On examination, he is icteric, 
PR-122 /min and BP- 88/64 mmHg. The following finding is seen on his abdomen. Which of 
the following is false regarding his initial management? 333 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: pRBC is used to maintain Hb between 7-9g/dL
options.c: IV octreotide is used to acheive hemostasis
options.d: Upper GI endoscopy is only performed after 12 hours

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing caput-medusae is suggestive of acute 
esophageal variceal bleeding due to portal hypertension. Upper GI endoscopy is performed within 
12 hours after fluid resuscitation in variceal bleeding. The management of esophageal variceal bleeding involves: • Resuscitation with IV fluids, airway protection, and oxygen • Blood transfusion to maintain Hb between 7-9g/dL • Antibiotic prophylaxis with ceftriaxone before endoscopy • An attempt at hemostasis with octreotide or terlipressin or vasopressin • Upper GI endoscopy within 12 hours after fluid resuscitation to confirm the source of the bleed • Endoscopic variceal ligation of sclerotherapy • In case, of failure or rebleeding - TIPS Nonselective beta-blockers like propranolol and nadolol are used in the prophylaxis of variceal 
bleeding. 344 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is false about the given image?

options.a: Esophageal balloon should be deflated for about 5 mins every 6 hours
options.b: Gastric balloon should be inflated first
options.c: Pressure in the oesophageal balloon should not exceed 60 mm Hg.
options.d: Endotracheal intubation prior to tube insertion reduces the risk of pulmonary aspiration

questions.explanation:
The given image shows Sengstaken-Blakemore tube. Pressure in the oesophageal balloon should 
not exceed 45 mm Hg. It is used for balloon tamponade in variceal hemorrhage when medical therapy fails or is not 
available. Initially, only the gastric balloon should be inflated, with 200– 250 mL of air, as this 
will usually control bleeding. The oesophageal balloon is used in continued bleeding, it should be 
deflated for about 5 minutes every 6 hours to avoid oesophageal mucosal damage. Endotracheal intubation prior to tube insertion reduces the risk of pulmonary aspiration. 345 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient with hereditary hemochromatosis shows marked confusion and gross 
disorientation. He is drowsy but responds to pain and voice stimuli. What is the most likely 
grading of hepatic encephalopathy in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Gross disorientation with an intact response to pain and voice suggest grade 3 hepatic 
encephalopathy. Hepatic encephalopathy is the alteration of mental status and cognitive function occurring in liver 
failure. This occurs due to the failure of removal of gut-derived neurotoxins like ammonia by liver. 
These neurotoxins enter the brain leading to the development of symptoms.

questions.question: Question 16: What is the earliest symptom of hepatic encephalopathy?
questions.explanation: The earliest symptom of hepatic encephalopathy is an alteration in sleep pattern. Other signs and symptoms of hepatic encephalopathy include: • Asterixis also called the flapping tremor • Mood changes and inappropriate behavior • Disorientation and confusion

questions.question:
Question 17: A cirrhotic patient was admitted following variceal bleeding. On the 3rd day of his hospital 
stay, he appears to be drowsy and confused. His wife reports that he had been awake 
throughout the previous night. On examination, flapping tremors were noticed. Which of the 
following is least likely to have precipitated his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hepatic encephalopathy. Antibiotics are unlikely to 
precipitate hepatic encephalopathy. The common precipitating factors of hepatic encephalopathy are : • Gastrointestinal bleeding • Infections like SBP or UTIs • Peritoneal tap • Constipation • Renal failure • Hypovolemia • Hypoxia • Drugs - sedatives, antidepressants, diuretics • Hypoglycemia • Hypokalemia

questions.question:
Question 18: 335 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following antibiotics could be used in the treatment of patients with hepatic 
encephalopathy?
questions.explanation:
Rifaximin can be used in the treatment of hepatic encephalopathy. It lowers blood ammonia 
levels. 346 
Sold by @itachibot Treatment of hepatic encephalopathy includes: • Correction of precipitating factors • Lactulose - decreased GI transit time due to cathartic actions leading to increased elimination of 
ammonia • Rifaximin - lowers the blood ammonia levels • L-ornithine L-aspartate - stimulate the urea cycle, with resulting loss of ammonia

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is not part of the diagnostic criteria of hepatorenal syndrome?

options.a: 50% increase in creatinine from baseline within 7 days
options.b: Rise in creatinine of 0.3 mg/dl in 48 hours
options.d: No recent use of nephrotoxic agent

questions.explanation:
The absence of shock is a part of the diagnostic criteria for hepatorenal syndrome. Hepatorenal syndrome is a progressive renal failure in patients with acute or chronic liver 
disease. The diagnostic criteria for hepatorenal syndrome include: • Cirrhosis with ascites • Diagnosis of acute kidney injury (AKI) • Increase in serum creatinine of  0.3mg/dL in 48 hours, OR • 50% increase in serum creatinine from baseline within 7 days • Absence of shock • No evidence of recent use of nephrotoxic agents • Absence of intrinsic renal disease

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following clinical features is most likely to be seen in patients with 
hepatopulmonary syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, platypnea is most likely to be seen in patients with hepatopulmonary 
syndrome. Hepatopulmonary syndrome is characterized by a triad of liver disease, hypoxemia, and 
intrapulmonary vascular dilatations. Most patients have dyspnea on exertion. The classic clinical 
manifestations are: • Platypnea - Increase in dyspnea when the patient moves from supine to upright position • Orthodeoxia - Decrease in arterial oxygen tension when the patient moves from supine to 
upright position The hypoxemia is due to a ventilation-perfusion mismatch which causes an 
increased alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient. The most sensitive test for diagnosis is contrast bubble 
echocardiography. Liver transplantation is the definitive treatment of this condition following which the symptoms 
subside. 347 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 21: A 52-year-old man presents with oliguria, abdominal distension, and pedal edema. His 
medical records show long-standing cirrhosis with multiple hospitalisations for ascites and 
hepatic encephalopathy. His lab reports are given below. What is the best treatment for his 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hepatorenal syndrome. The best treatment modality for 
it is liver transplantation. Hepatorenal syndrome is characterised by a rise in: • AST • ALT • Total bilirubin • Serum creatinine • Blood urea nitrogen (BUN). Management of hepatorenal syndrome include: • Norepinephrine • Octreotide • Terlipressin • Midodrine • Intravenous albumin • Liver transplantation- definitive treatment

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following conditions is not a MELD exception?
questions.explanation:
Chronic Hepatitis B is not a MELD exception. MELD (Model for End-stage Liver Disease) score is used to prioritize patients awaiting liver 
transplantation. However, there are certain diseases that impair patient survival and are not 
accounted for in the MELD score. Patients with these diseases are given upgraded MELD points 
to accurately represent the mortality risk and these conditions are called MELD exceptions. The MELD exceptions include:- • Portopulmonary hypertension • Hepatocellular carcinoma • Familial amyloid polyneuropathy • Primary hyperoxaluria (necessitating liver-kidney transplantation) • Cystic fibrosis with liver disease • Highly selected cases of hilar cholangiocarcinoma. • Hepatopulmonary syndrome • Hepatic artery thrombosis 7–14 days post-liver transplantation. 348 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 23: Which among the following is false?

options.a: Components of MELD (Model for end stage liver disease) scoring system are creatinine,
options.b: Components of CTP(Child Turcotte Pugh) score are albumin, bilirubin, INR, ascites,
options.c: Components of CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh ) are creatinine, bilirubin, International normalized
options.d: MELD score is used to assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation

questions.explanation:
The Child Turcotte Pugh (CTP) score does not include creatinine. The components of the CTP score are: • Albumin • Bilirubin • International normalized ratio (INR) • Ascites • Encephalopathy The Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD 3.0) is used to prioritize patients awaiting liver 
transplantation and includes: • Female sex • Bilirubin • Albumin • Serum sodium (mEq/L) • INR (International Normalized ratio) • Creatinine

questions.question:
Question 24: What is the Child-Turcotte-Pugh class for the patient who has a serum bilirubin 2.5 mg/dl, 
serum albumin 3 g/dl, prothrombin time increased by 5 seconds (INR = 2), no 
encephalopathy, and mild ascites?

options.b: H pylori infection increases the risk
options.c: Even low dose of a NSAID can cause ulcers
options.d: Concomitant use of glucocorticoids decreases the risk

questions.explanation:
The given patient belongs to Child-Turcotte-Pugh class B. The score can be calculated as follows: Serum bilirubin-2.5mg/dl: 2 Serum albumin-3g/dl: 2 Prothrombin time-5 seconds or INR-2: 2 No encephalopathy: 1 Mild ascites: 2 Therefore, the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score is (2+2+2+1+2)= 9 which is included in Class B. 349 
Sold by @itachibot Peptic Ulcer Disease and Related Disorders
